(Which all the while ran blood) great Cæsar fell.
O what a fall was there, my Countrymen?
Then I, and you, and all of vs fell downe,
Whil'st bloody Treason flourish'd ouer vs.
O now you weepe, and I perceiue you feele
The dint of pitty: These are gracious droppes.
Kinde Soules, what weepe you, when you but behold
Our Cæsars Vesture wounded? Looke you heere,
Heere is Himselfe, marr'd as you see with Traitors.
O pitteous spectacle!
O Noble Cæsar!
O wofull day!
O Traitors, Villaines!
O most bloody sight!
We will be reueng'd: Reuenge
About, seeke, burne, fire, kill, slay,
Let not a Traitor liue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stay Country‑men.
Peace there, heare the Noble Antony.

Wee'l heare him, wee'l follow him, wee'l dy with
him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l:
Good Friends, sweet Friends, let me not stirre
(you vp
To such a sodaine Flood of Mutiny:
They that haue done this Deede, are honourable.
What priuate greefes they haue, alas I know not,
That made them do it: They are Wise, and Honourable,
And will no doubt with Reasons answer you.
I come not (Friends) to steale away your hearts,
I am no Orator, as Brutus is:
But (as you know me all) a plaine blunt man
That loue my Friend, and that they know full well,
That gaue me publike leaue to speake of him:
For I haue neyther writ nor words, nor worth,
Action, nor Vtterance, nor the power of Speech,
To stirre mens Blood. I onely speake right on:
I tell you that, which you your selues do know,
Shew you sweet Cæsars wounds, poor poor dum mouths
And bid them speake for me: But were I Brutus,
And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony
Would ruffle vp your Spirits, and put a Tongue
In euery Wound of Cæsar, that should moue
The stones of Rome, to rise and Mutiny.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Wee'l Mutiny.
Wee'l burne the house of Brutus.
Away then, come, seeke the Conspirators.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yet heare me Countrymen, yet heare me speake

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Peace hoe, heare Antony, most Noble Antony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why Friends, you go to do you know not what:
Wherein hath Cæsar thus deseru'd your loues?
Alas you know not, I must tell you then:
You haue forgot the Will I told you of.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Most true, the Will, let's stay and heare the Wil.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Heere is the Will, and vnder Cæsars Seale:
To euery Roman Citizen he giues,
To euery seuerall man, seuenty fiue Drachmaes.

sp.speaker: 2 Ple.
sp.l: Most Noble Cæsar, wee'l reuenge his death.

sp.speaker: 3 Ple.
sp.l: O Royall Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Heare me with patience.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Peace hoe

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Moreouer, he hath left you all his Walkes,
His priuate Arbors, and new‑planted Orchards,
On this side Tyber, he hath left them you,
And to your heyres for euer: common pleasures
To walke abroad, and recreate your selues.
Heere was a Cæsar: when comes such another?

sp.speaker: 1. Ple.
sp.l: Neuer, neuer: come, away, away:
Wee'l burne his body in the holy place,
And with the Brands fire the Traitors houses.
Take vp the body.

sp.speaker: 2. Ple.
sp.l: Go fetch fire.

sp.speaker: 3. Ple.
sp.l: Plucke downe Benches.

sp.speaker: 4. Ple.
sp.l: Plucke downe Formes, Windowes, any thing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now let it worke: Mischeefe thou art a‑foot,
Take thou what course thou wilt.
How now Fellow?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, Octauius is already come to Rome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where is hee?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He and Lepidus are at Cæsars house.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And thither will I straight, to visit him:
He comes vpon a wish. Fortune is merry,
And in this mood will giue vs any thing.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I heard him say, Brutus and Cassius
Are rid like Madmen through the Gates of Rome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Belike they had some notice of the people
How I had moued them. Bring me to Octauius.

div.head: [Act 3, Scene 3]
div.stage: Enter Cinna the Poet, and after him the Plebeians.

sp.speaker: Cinna.
sp.l: I dreamt to night, that I did feast with Cæsar,
And things vnluckily charge my Fantasie:
I haue no will to wander foorth of doores,
Yet something leads me foorth.

sp.p: What is your name?
Whether are you going?
Whre do you dwell?
Are you a married man, or a Batchellor?
Answer euery man directly.
I, and breefely.
I, and wisely.
I, and truly, you were best.

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p:
What is my name? Whether am I going? Where
do I dwell? Am I a married man, or a Batchellour? Then
to answer euery man, directly and breefely, wisely and
truly: wisely I say, I am a Batchellor.

That's as much as to say, they are fooles that mar­
rie: you'l beare me a bang for that I feare: proceede di­
rectly.

sp.speaker: Cinna.
sp.p: Directly I am going to Cæsars Funerall.
As a Friend, or an Enemy?

sp.speaker: Cinna.
sp.p: As a friend.
That matter is answered directly.
For your dwelling: breefely.

sp.speaker: Cinna.
sp.p: Breefely, I dwell by the Capitoll.
Your name sir, truly.

sp.speaker: Cinna.
sp.p: Truly, my name is Cinna.
Teare him to peeces, hee's a Conspirator.

sp.speaker: Cinna.
sp.p: I am Cinna the Poet, I am Cinna the Poet.

Teare him for his bad verses, teare him for his bad
Verses.

sp.speaker: Cin.
sp.p: I am not Cinna the Conspirator.

It is no matter, his name's Cinna, plucke but his
name out of his heart, and turne him going.

Teare him, tear him; Come Brands hoe, Firebrands:
to Brutus, to Cassius, burne all. Some to Decius House,
and some to Caska's; some to Ligarius: Away, go.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: These many then shall die, their names are prickt

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Your Brother too must dye: consent you Lepidus?

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: I do consent.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Pricke him downe Antony.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: Vpon condition Publius shall not liue,
Who is your Sisters sonne, Marke Antony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He shall not liue; looke, with a spot I dam him.
But Lepidus, go you to Cæsars house:
Fetch the Will hither, and we shall determine
How to cut off some charge in Legacies.

sp.speaker: Lep.
sp.l: What? shall I finde you heere?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Or heere, or at the Capitoll.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is a slight vnmeritable man,
Meet to be sent on Errands: is it fit
The three‑fold World diuided, he should stand
One of the three to share it?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: So you thought him,
And tooke his voyce who should be prickt to dye
In our blacke Sentence and Proscription.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Octauius, I haue seene more dayes then you,
And though we lay these Honours on this man,
To ease our selues of diuers sland'rous loads,
He shall but beare them, as the Asse beares Gold,
To groane and swet vnder the Businesse,
Either led or driuen, as we point the way:
And hauing brought our Treasure, where we will,
Then take we downe his Load, and turne him off
(Like to the empty Asse) to shake his eares,
And graze in Commons.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: You may do your will:
But hee's a tried, and valiant Souldier.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So is my Horse Octauius, and for that
I do appoint him store of Prouender.
It is a Creature that I teach to fight,
To winde, to stop, to run directly on:
His corporall Motion, gouern'd by my Spirit,
And in some taste, is Lepidus but so:
He must be taught, and train'd, and bid go forth:
A barren spirited Fellow; one that feeds
On Obiects, Arts, and Imitations.
Which out of vse, and stal'de by other men
Begin his fashion. Do not talke of him,
But as a property: and now Octauius,
Listen great things. Brutus and Cassius
Are leuying Powers; We must straight make head:
Therefore let our Alliance be combin'd,
Our best Friends made, our meanes stretcht,
And let vs presently go sit in Councell,
How couert matters may be best disclos'd,
And open Perils surest answered.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Let vs do so: for we are at the stake,
And bayed about with many Enemies,
And some that smile haue in their hearts I feare
Millions of Mischeefes.

div.head: [Act 4, Scene 2]
div.stage:
Drum. Enter Brutus, Lucillius, and the Army. Titinius
and Pindarus meete them.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Stand ho.

sp.speaker: Lucil.
sp.l: Giue the word ho, and Stand.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: What now Lucillius, is Cassius neere?

sp.speaker: Lucil.
sp.l: He is at hand, and Pindarus is come
To do you salutation from his Master.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: He greets me well. Your Master Pindarus
In his owne change, or by ill Officers,
Hath giuen me some worthy cause to wish
Things done, vndone: But if he be at hand
I shall be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: I do not doubt
But that my Noble Master will appeare
Such as he is, full of regard, and Honour.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: He is not doubted. A word Lucillius
How he receiu'd you: let me be resolu'd.

sp.speaker: Lucil.
sp.l: With courtesie, and with respect enough,
But not with such familiar instances,
Nor with such free and friendly Conference
As he hath vs'd of old.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Thou hast describ'd
A hot Friend, cooling: Euer note Lucillius,
When Loue begins to sicken and decay
It vseth an enforced Ceremony.
There are no trickes, in plaine and simple Faith:
But hollow men, like Horses hot at hand,
Make gallant shew, and promise of their Mettle:
But when they should endure the bloody Spurre,
They fall their Crests, and like deceitfull Iades
Sinke in the Triall. Comes his Army on?

sp.speaker: Lucil.
sp.l: They meane this night in Sardis to be quarter'd:
The greater part, the Horse in generall
Are come with Cassius.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Hearke, he is arriu'd:
March gently on to meete him.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Stand ho.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Stand ho, speake the word along.
Stand.
Stand.
Stand.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Most Noble Brother, you haue done me wrong.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Iudge me you Gods; wrong I mine Enemies?
And if not so, how should I wrong a Brother.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Brutus, this sober forme of yours, hides wrongs,
And when you do them⸺

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Cassius, be content,
Speake your greefes softly, I do know you well.
Before the eyes of both our Armies heere
(Which should perceiue nothing but Loue from vs)
Let vs not wrangle. Bid them moue away:
Then in my Tent Cassius enlarge your Greefes,
And I will giue you Audience.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Pindarus,
Bid our Commanders leade their Charges off
A little from this ground.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lucillius, do you the like, and let no man
Come to our Tent, till we haue done our Conference.
Let Lucius and Titinius guard our doore.

div.head: [Act 4, Scene 3]

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: That you haue wrong'd me, doth appear in this:
You haue condemn'd, and noted Lucius Pella
For taking Bribes heere of the Sardians;
Wherein my Letters, praying on his side,
Because I knew the man was slighted off.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: You wrong'd your selfe to write in such a case.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: In such a time as this, it is not meet
That euery nice offence should beare his Comment.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Let me tell you Cassius, you your selfe
Are much condemn'd to haue an itching Palme,
To sell, and Mart your Offices for Gold
To Vndeseruers.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: I, an itching Palme?
You know that you are Brutus that speakes this,
Or by the Gods, this speech were else your last.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: The name of Cassius Honors this corruption,
And Chasticement doth therefore hide his head.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Chasticement?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Remember March, the Ides of March remēber remember :
Did not great Iulius bleede for Iustice sake?
What Villaine touch'd his body, that did stab,
And not for Iustice? What? Shall one of Vs,
That strucke the Formost man of all this World,
But for supporting Robbers: shall we now,
Contaminate our fingers, with base Bribes?
And sell the mighty space of our large Honors
For so much trash, as may be grasped thus?
I had rather be a Dogge, and bay the Moone,
Then such a Roman.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Brutus, baite not me,
Ile not indure it: you forget your selfe
To hedge me in. I am a Souldier, I,
Older in practice, Abler then your selfe
To make Conditions.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Go too: you are not Cassius.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I say, you are not.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Vrge me no more, I shall forget my selfe:
Haue minde vpon your health: Tempt me no farther.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Away slight man.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Heare me, for I will speake.
Must I giue way, and roome to your rash Choller?
Shall I be frighted, when a Madman stares?

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: O ye Gods, ye Gods, Must I endure all this?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: All this? I more: Fret till your proud hart break.
Go shew your Slaues how Chollericke you are,
And make your Bondmen tremble. Must I bouge?
Must I obserue you? Must I stand and crouch
Vnder your Testie Humour? By the Gods,
You shall digest the Venom of your Spleene
Though it do Split you. For, from this day forth,
Ile vse you for my Mirth, yea for my Laughter
When you are Waspish.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Is it come to this?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: You say, you are a better Souldier:
Let it appeare so; make your vaunting true,
And it shall please me well. For mine owne part,
I shall be glad to learne of Noble men.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: You wrong me euery way:
You wrong me Brutus:
I saide, an Elder Souldier, not a Better.
Did I say Better?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: If you did, I care not.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l:
When Cæsar liu'd, he durst not thus haue mou'd
(me.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Peace, peace, you durst not so haue tempted him.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: I durst not.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: What? durst not tempt him?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: For your life you durst not.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Do not presume too much vpon my Loue,
I may do that I shall be sorry for.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: You haue done that you should be sorry for.
There is no terror Cassius in your threats:
For I am Arm'd so strong in Honesty,
That they passe by me, as the idle winde,
Which I respect not. I did send to you
For certaine summes of Gold, which you deny'd me,
For I can raise no money by vile meanes:
By Heauen, I had rather Coine my Heart,
And drop my blood for Drachmaes, then to wring
From the hard hands of Peazants, their vile trash
By any indirection. I did send
To you for Gold to pay my Legions,
Which you deny'd me: was that done like Cassius?
Should I haue answer'd Caius Cassius so?
When Marcus Brutus growes so Couetous,
To locke such Rascall Counters from his Friends,
Be ready Gods with all your Thunder‑bolts,
Dash him to peeces.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: I deny'd you not.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: You did.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: I did not. He was but a Foole
That brought my answer back. Brutus hath riu'd my hart:
A Friend should beare his Friends infirmities;
But Brutus makes mine greater then they are.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I do not, till you practice them on me.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: You loue me not.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I do not like your faults.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: A friendly eye could neuer see such faults.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: A Flatterers would not, though they do appeare
As huge as high Olympus.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Come Antony, and yong Octauius come,
Reuenge your selues alone on Cassius,
For Cassius is a‑weary of the World:
Hated by one he loues, brau'd by his Brother,
Check'd like a bondman, all his faults obseru'd,
Set in a Note‑booke, learn'd, and con'd by roate
To cast into my Teeth. O I could weepe
My Spirit from mine eyes. There is my Dagger,
And heere my naked Breast: Within, a Heart
Deerer then Pluto's Mine, Richer then Gold:
If that thou bee'st a Roman, take it foorth.
I that deny'd thee Gold, will giue my Heart:
Strike as thou did'st at Cæsar: For I know,
When thou did'st hate him worst, yͧ thou loued'st him better
Then euer thou loued'st Cassius.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Sheath your Dagger:
Be angry when you will, it shall haue scope:
Do what you will, Dishonor, shall be Humour.
O Cassius, you are yoaked with a Lambe
That carries Anger, as the Flint beares fire,
Who much inforced, shewes a hastie Sparke,
And straite is cold agen.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Hath Cassius liu'd
To be but Mirth and Laughter to his Brutus,
When greefe and blood ill temper'd, vexeth him?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: When I spoke that, I was ill temper'd too.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Do you confesse so much? Giue me your hand.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: And my heart too.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: O Brutus!

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Haue not you loue enough to beare with me,
When that rash humour which my Mother gaue me
Makes me forgetfull.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Yes Cassius, and from henceforth
When you are ouer‑earnest with your Brutus,
Hee'l thinke your Mother chides, and leaue you so.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Let me go in to see the Generals,
There is some grudge betweene 'em, 'tis not meete
They be alone.

sp.speaker: Lucil.
sp.l: You shall not come to them.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Nothing but death shall stay me.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: How now? What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: For shame you Generals; what do you meane?
Loue, and be Friends, as two such men should bee,
For I haue seene more yeeres I'me sure then yee.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Ha, ha, how vildely doth this Cynicke rime?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Get you hence sirra: Sawcy Fellow, hence.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Beare with him Brutus, 'tis his fashion.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Ile know his humor, when he knowes his time:
What should the Warres do with these Iigging Fooles?
Companion, hence.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Away, away be gone.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lucillius and Titinius bid the Commanders
Prepare to lodge their Companies to night.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: And come your selues, & bring Messala with you
Immediately to vs.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Lucius, a bowle of Wine.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I did not thinke you could haue bin so angry.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: O Cassius, I am sicke of many greefes.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Of your Philosophy you make no vse,
If you giue place to accidentall euils.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: No man beares sorrow better. Portia is dead.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Ha? Portia?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: She is dead.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: How scap'd I killing, when I crost you so?
O insupportable, and touching losse!
Vpon what sicknesse?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Impatient of my absence,
And greefe, that yong Octauius with Mark Antony
Haue made themselues so strong: For with her death
That tydings came. With this she fell distract,
And (her Attendants absent) swallow'd fire.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: And dy'd so?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Euen so.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: O ye immortall Gods!

div.stage: Enter Boy with Wine, and Tapers.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Speak no more of her: Giue me a bowl of wine,
In this I bury all vnkindnesse Cassius.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: My heart is thirsty for that Noble pledge.
Fill Lucius, till the Wine ore‑swell the Cup:
I cannot drinke too much of Brutus loue.

sp.speaker: Brutus.
sp.l: Come in Titinius:
Welcome good Messala:
Now sit we close about this Taper heere,
And call in question our necessities.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Portia, art thou gone?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: No more I pray you.
Messala, I haue heere receiued Letters,
That yong Octauius, and Marke Antony
Come downe vpon vs with a mighty power,
Bending their Expedition toward Philippi.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: My selfe haue Letters of the selfe‑same Tenure.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: With what Addition

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: That by proscription, and billes of Outlarie,
Octauius, Antony, and Lepidus,
Haue put to death, an hundred Senators.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Therein our Letters do not well agree:
Mine speake of seuenty Senators, that dy'de
By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Cicero one?

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: Cicero is dead, and by that order of proscription
Had you your Letters from your wife, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: No Messala.

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: Nor nothing in your Letters writ of her?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Nothing Messala.

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: That me thinkes is strange.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why aske you?
Heare you ought of her, in yours?

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Now as you are a Roman tell me true.

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: Then like a Roman, beare the truth I tell,
For certaine she is dead, and by strange manner.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why farewell Portia: We must die Messala:
With meditating that she must dye once,
I haue the patience to endure it now.

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: Euen so great men, great losses shold indure.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: I haue as much of this in Art as you,
But yet my Nature could not beare it so.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Well, to our worke aliue. What do you thinke
Of marching to Philippi presently.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: I do not thinke it good.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Your reason?

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: This it is:
'Tis better that the Enemie seeke vs,
So shall he waste his meanes, weary his Souldiers,
Doing himselfe offence, whil'st we lying still,
Are full of rest, defence, and nimblenesse.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Good reasons must of force giue place to better:
The people 'twixt Philippi, and this ground
Do stand but in a forc'd affection:
For they haue grug'd vs Contribution.
The Enemy, marching along by them,
By them shall make a fuller number vp,
Come on refresht, new added, and encourag'd:
From which aduantage shall we cut him off.
If at Philippi we do face him there,
These people at our backe.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Heare me good Brother.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Vnder your pardon. You must note beside,
That we haue tride the vtmost of our Friends:
Our Legions are brim full, our cause is ripe,
The Enemy encreaseth euery day,
We at the height, are readie to decline.
There is a Tide in the affayres of men,
Which taken at the Flood, leades on to Fortune:
Omitted, all the voyage of their life,
Is bound in Shallowes, and in Miseries.
On such a full Sea are we now a‑float,
And we must take the current when it serues,
Or loose our Ventures.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Then with your will go on: wee'l along
Our selues, and meet them at Philippi.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: The deepe of night is crept vpon our talke,
And Nature must obey Necessitie,
Which we will niggard with a little rest:
There is no more to say.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: No more, good night,
Early to morrow will we rise, and hence.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Lucius my Gowne: farewell good Messala,
Good night Titinius: Noble, Noble Cassius,
Good night, and good repose.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: O my deere Brother:
This was an ill beginning of the night:
Neuer come such diuision 'tweene our soules:
Let it not Brutus.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Euery thing is well.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Good night my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Good night good Brother.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Messa. Good night Lord Brutus.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Farwell euery one.
Giue me the Gowne. Where is thy Instrument?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Heere in the Tent.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: What, thou speak'st drowsily?
Poore knaue I blame thee not, thou art ore‑watch'd.
Call Claudio, and some other of my men,
Ile haue them sleepe on Cushions in my Tent.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Varrus, and Claudio.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Cals my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I pray you sirs, lye in my Tent and sleepe,
It may be I shall raise you by and by
On businesse to my Brother Cassius.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: So please you, we will stand,
And watch your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I will it not haue it so: Lye downe good sirs,
It may be I shall otherwise bethinke me.
Looke Lucius, heere's the booke I sought for so:
I put it in the pocket of my Gowne.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I was sure your Lordship did not giue it me.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Beare with me good Boy, I am much forgetfull.
Canst thou hold vp thy heauie eyes a‑while,
And touch thy Instrument a straine or two.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I my Lord, an't please you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: It does my Boy:
I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is my duty Sir.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: I should not vrge thy duty past thy might,
I know yong bloods looke for a time of rest.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I haue slept my Lord already.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: It was well done, and thou shalt sleepe againe:
I will not hold thee long. If I do liue,
I will be good to thee.
This is a sleepy Tune: O Murd'rous slumber!
Layest thou thy Leaden Mace vpon my Boy,
That playes thee Musicke? Gentle knaue good night:
I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee:
If thou do'st nod, thou break'st thy Instrument,
Ile take it from thee, and (good Boy) good night.
Let me see, let me see; is not the Leafe turn'd downe
Where I left reading? Heere it is I thinke.
How ill this Taper burnes. Ha! Who comes heere?
I thinke it is the weakenesse of mine eyes
That shapes this monstrous Apparition.
It comes vpon me: Art thou any thing?
Art thou some God, some Angell, or some Diuell,
That mak'st my blood cold, and my haire to stare?
Speake to me, what thou art.

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.l: Thy euill Spirit Brutus?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why com'st thou?

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.l: To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Well: then I shall see thee againe?

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.l: I, at Philippi.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Why I will see thee at Philippi then:
Now I haue taken heart, thou vanishest.
Ill Spirit, I would hold more talke with thee.

Boy, Lucius, Varrus, Claudio, Sirs: Awake:
Claudio.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The strings my Lord, are false.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: He thinkes he still is at his Instrument.
Lucius, awake.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l:
Did'st thou dreame Lucius, that thou so cryedst
out?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Lord, I do not know that I did cry.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Yes that thou did'st: Did'st thou see any thing?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nothing my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Sleepe againe Lucius: Sirra Claudio, Fellow,
Thou: Awake.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why did you so cry out sirs, in your sleepe?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Did we my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I: saw you any thing?

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: No my Lord, I saw nothing.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Nor I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Go, and commend me to my Brother Cassius:
Bid him set on his Powres betimes before,
And we will follow.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: It shall be done my Lord.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
[Act 5, Scene 1]
div.stage: Enter Octauius, Antony, and their Army.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Now Antony, our hopes are answered,
You said the Enemy would not come downe,
But keepe the Hilles and vpper Regions:
It proues not so: their battailes are at hand,
They meane to warne vs at Philippi heere:
Answering before we do demand of them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tut I am in their bosomes, and I know
Wherefore they do it: They could be content
To visit other places, and come downe
With fearefull brauery: thinking by this face
To fasten in our thoughts that they haue Courage;
But 'tis not so.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Prepare you Generals,
The Enemy comes on in gallant shew:
Their bloody signe of Battell is hung out,
And something to be done immediately.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Octauius, leade your Battaile softly on
Vpon the left hand of the euen Field.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Vpon the right hand I, keepe thou the left.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why do you crosse me in this exigent.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: I do not crosse you: but I will do so.

div.stage: Drum. Enter Brutus, Cassius, & their Army.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: They stand, and would haue parley.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Stand fast Titinius, we must out and talke.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Mark Antony, shall we giue signe of Battaile?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No Cæsar, we will answer on their Charge.
Make forth, the Generals would haue some words.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Stirre not vntill the Signall.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Words before blowes: is it so Countrymen?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Not that we loue words better, as you do.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Good words are better then bad strokes Octauius.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: In your bad strokes Brutus, you giue good words
Witnesse the hole you made in Cæsars heart,
Crying long liue, Haile Cæsar.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Antony,
The posture of your blowes are yet vnknowne;
But for your words, they rob the Hibla Bees,
And leaue them Hony‑lesse.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not stinglesse too.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: O yes, and soundlesse too:
For you haue stolne their buzzing Antony,
And very wisely threat before you sting.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Villains: you did not so, when your vile daggers
Hackt one another in the sides of Cæsar:
You shew'd your teethes like Apes,
And fawn'd like Hounds,
And bow'd like Bondmen, kissing Cæsars feete;
Whil'st damned Caska, like a Curre, behinde
Strooke Cæsar on the necke. O you Flatterers.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Flatterers? Now Brutus thanke your selfe,
This tongue had not offended so to day.
If Cassius might haue rul'd.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Come, come, the cause. If arguing make vs swet,
The proofe of it will turne to redder drops:
Looke, I draw a Sword against Conspirators,
When thinke you that the Sword goes vp againe?
Neuer till Cæsars three and thirtie wounds
Be well aueng'd; or till another Cæsar
Haue added slaughter to the Sword of Traitors.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Cæsar, thou canst not dye by Traitors hands.
Vnlesse thou bring'st them with thee.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: So I hope:
I was not borne to dye on Brutus Sword.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: O if thou wer't the Noblest of thy Straine,
Yong‑man, thou could'st not dye more honourable.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: A peeuish School‑boy, worthles of such Honor
Ioyn'd with a Masker, and a Reueller.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Old Cassius still.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Come Antony: away:
Defiance Traitors, hurle we in your teeth.
If you dare fight to day, come to the Field;
If not, when you haue stomackes.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Why now blow winde, swell Billow,
And swimme Barke:
The Storme is vp, and all is on the hazard.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Ho Lucillius, hearke, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Messala.

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: What sayes my Generall?

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Messala, this is my Birth‑day: at this very day
Was Cassius borne. Giue me thy hand Messala:
Be thou my witnesse, that against my will
(As Pompey was) am I compell'd to set
Vpon one Battell all our Liberties.
You know, that I held Epicurus strong,
And his Opinion: Now I change my minde,
And partly credit things that do presage.
Comming from Sardis, on our former Ensigne
Two mighty Eagles fell, and there they pearch'd,
Gorging and feeding from our Soldiers hands,
Who to Philippi heere consorted vs:
This Morning are they fled away, and gone,
And in their steeds, do Rauens, Crowes, and Kites
Fly ore our heads, and downward looke on vs
As we were sickely prey; their shadowes seeme
A Canopy most fatall, vnder which
Our Army lies, ready to giue vp the Ghost.

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: Beleeue not so.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: I but beleeue it partly,
For I am fresh of spirit, and resolu'd
To meete all perils, very constantly.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Euen so Lucillius.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Now most Noble Brutus,
The Gods to day stand friendly, that we may
Louers in peace, leade on our dayes to age.
But since the affayres of men rests still incertaine,
Let's reason with the worst that may befall.
If we do lose this Battaile, then is this
The very last time we shall speake together:
What are you then determined to do?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Euen by the rule of that Philosophy,
By which I did blame Cato, for the death
Which he did giue himselfe, I know not how:
But I do finde it Cowardly, and vile,
For feare of what might fall, so to preuent
The time of life, arming my selfe with patience,
To stay the prouidence of some high Powers,
That gouerne vs below.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Then, if we loose this Battaile,
You are contented to be led in Triumph
Thorow the streets of Rome.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: No Cassius, no:
Thinke not thou Noble Romane,
That euer Brutus will go bound to Rome,
He beares too great a minde. But this same day
Must end that worke, the Ides of March begun.
And whether we shall meete againe, I know not:
Therefore our euerlasting farewell take:
For euer, and for euer, farewell Cassius,
If we do meete againe, why we shall smile;
If not, why then this parting was well made.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: For euer, and for euer, farewell Brutus:
If we do meete againe, wee'l smile indeede;
If not, 'tis true, this parting was well made.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why then leade on. O that a man might know
The end of this dayes businesse, ere it come:
But it sufficeth, that the day will end,
And then the end is knowne. Come ho, away.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Ride, ride Messala, ride and giue these Billes
Vnto the Legions, on the other side.
Let them set on at once: for I perceiue
But cold demeanor in Octauio's wing:
And sodaine push giues them the ouerthrow:
Ride, ride Messala, let them all come downe.

div.head: [Act 5, Scene 3]

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: O looke Titinius, looke, the Villaines flye:
My selfe haue to mine owne turn'd Enemy:
This Ensigne heere of mine was turning backe,
I slew the Coward, and did take it from him.

sp.speaker: Titin.
sp.l: O Cassius, Brutus gaue the word too early,
Who hauing some aduantage on Octauius,
Tooke it too eagerly: his Soldiers fell to spoyle,
Whilst we by Antony are all inclos'd.

sp.speaker: Pind.
sp.l: Fly further off my Lord: flye further off,
Mark Antony is in your Tents my Lord:
Flye therefore Noble Cassius, flye farre off.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: This Hill is farre enough. Looke, look Titinius
Are those my Tents where I perceiue the fire?

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: They are, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Titinius, if thou louest me,
Mount thou my horse, and hide thy spurres in him,
Till he haue brought thee vp to yonder Troopes
And heere againe, that I may rest assur'd
Whether yond Troopes, are Friend or Enemy.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: I will be heere againe, euen with a thought.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Go Pindarus, get higher on that hill,
My sight was euer thicke: regard Titinius,
And tell me what thou not'st about the Field.
This day I breathed first, Time is come round,
And where I did begin, there shall I end,
My life is run his compasse. Sirra, what newes?

sp.speaker: Pind.
sp.l: Aboue. O my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: What newes?

sp.speaker: Pind.
sp.l: Titinius is enclosed round about
With Horsemen, that make to him on the Spurre,
Yet he spurres on. Now they are almost on him:
Now Titinius. Now some light: O he lights too.
Hee's tane.
And hearke, they shout for ioy.

sp.speaker: Cassi.
sp.l: Come downe, behold no more:
O Coward that I am, to liue so long,
To see my best Friend tane before my face
Come hither sirrah: In Parthia did I take thee Prisoner,
And then I swore thee, sauing of thy life,
That whatsoeuer I did bid thee do,
Thou should'st attempt it. Come now, keepe thine oath,
Now be a Free‑man, and with this good Sword
That ran through Cæsars bowels, search this bosome.
Stand not to answer: Heere, take thou the Hilts,
And when my face is couer'd, as 'tis now,
Guide thou the Sword⸺Cæsar, thou art reueng'd,
Euen with the Sword that kill'd thee.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: So, I am free,
Yet would not so haue beene
Durst I haue done my will. O Cassius,
Farre from this Country Pindarus shall run,
Where neuer Roman shall take note of him.

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: It is but change, Titinius: for Octauius
Is ouerthrowne by Noble Brutus power,
As Cassius Legions are by Antony.

sp.speaker: Titin.
sp.l: These tydings will well comfort Cassius.

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: Where did you leaue him.

sp.speaker: Titin.
sp.l: All disconsolate,
With Pindarus his Bondman, on this Hill.

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: Is not that he that lyes vpon the ground?

sp.speaker: Titin.
sp.l: He lies not like the Liuing. O my heart!

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: Is not that hee?

sp.speaker: Titin.
sp.l: No, this was he Messala,
But Cassius is no more. O setting Sunne:
As in thy red Rayes thou doest sinke to night;
So in his red blood Cassius day is set.
The Sunne of Rome is set. Our day is gone,
Clowds, Dewes, and Dangers come; our deeds are done:
Mistrust of my successe hath done this deed.

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: Mistrust of good successe hath done this deed.
O hatefull Error, Melancholies Childe:
Why do'st thou shew to the apt thoughts of men
The things that are not? O Error soone conceyu'd,
Thou neuer com'st vnto a happy byrth,
But kil'st the Mother that engendred thee.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: What Pindarus? Where art thou Pindarus?

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: Seeke him Titinius, whilst I go to meet
The Noble Brutus, thrusting this report
Into his eares; I may say thrusting it:
For piercing Steele, and Darts inuenomed,
Shall be as welcome to the eares of Brutus,
As tydings of this sight.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Hye you Messala,
And I will seeke for Pindarus the while:
Why did'st thou send me forth braue Cassius?
Did I not meet thy Friends, and did not they
Put on my Browes this wreath of Victorie,

And bid me giue it thee? Did'st thou not heare their.
(showts?
Alas, thou hast misconstrued euery thing.
But hold thee, take this Garland on thy Brow,
Thy Brutus bid me giue it thee, and I
Will do his bidding. Brutus, come apace,
And see how I regarded Caius Cassius:
By your leaue Gods: This is a Romans part,
Come Cassius Sword, and finde Titinius hart.

div.stage:
Alarum. Enter Brutus, Messala, yong Cato
Strato, Volumnius, and Lucillius.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Where, where Messala, doth his body lye?

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: Loe yonder, and Titinius mourning it.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Titinius face is vpward.

sp.speaker: Cato.
sp.l: He is slaine.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: O Iulius CÆsar, thou art mighty yet,
Thy Spirit walkes abroad, and turnes our Swords
In our owne proper Entrailes.

sp.speaker: Cato.
sp.l: Braue Titinius,
Looke where he haue not crown'd dead Cassius.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Are yet two Romans liuing such as these?
The last of all the Romans, far thee well:
It is impossible, that euer Rome
Should breed thy fellow. Friends I owe mo teares
To this dead man, then you shall see me pay.
I shall finde time, Cassius: I shall finde time.
Come therefore, and to Tharsus send his body,
His Funerals shall not be in our Campe,
Least it discomfort vs. Lucillius come,
And come yong Cato, let vs to the Field,
Labio and Flauio set our Battailes on:
'Tis three a clocke, and Romans yet ere night,
We shall try Fortune in a second fight.

div.head: [Act 5, Scene 4]
div.stage:
Alarum. Enter Brutus, Messala, Cato, Lucillius
and Flauius.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Yet Country‑men: O yet, hold vp your heads.

sp.speaker: Cato.
sp.l: What Bastard doth not? Who will go with me?
I will proclaime my name about the Field.
I am the Sonne of Marcus Cato, hoe.
A Foe to Tyrants, and my Countries Friend.
I am the Sonne of Marcus Cato, hoe.
And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I,
Brutus my Countries Friend: Know me for Brutus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O yong and Noble Cato, art thou downe?
Why now thou dyest, as brauely as Titinius,
And may'st be honour'd, being Cato's Sonne.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Yeeld, or thou dyest.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Onely I yeeld to dye:
There is so much, that thou wilt kill me straight:
Kill Brutus, and be honour'd in his death.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: We must not: a Noble Prisoner.

sp.speaker: 2. Sold.
sp.l: Roome hoe: tell Antony, Brutus is tane.

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.l: Ile tell thee newes. Heere comes the Generall,
Brutus is tane, Brutus is tane my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where is hee?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Safe Antony, Brutus is safe enough:
I dare assure thee, that no Enemy
Shall euer take aliue the Noble Brutus:
The Gods defend him from so great a shame,
When you do finde him, or aliue, or dead,
He will be found like Brutus, like himselfe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is not Brutus friend, but I assure you,
A prize no lesse in worth; keepe this man safe,
Giue him all kindnesse. I had rather haue
Such men my Friends, then Enemies. Go on,
And see where Brutus be aliue or dead,
And bring vs word, vnto Octauius Tent:
How euery thing is chanc'd.

div.head: [Act 5, Scene 5]
div.stage:
Enter Brutus, Dardanius, Clitus, Strato
and Volumnius.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l:
Come poore remaines of friends, rest on this
Rocke.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: Statillius shew'd the Torch‑light, but my Lord
He came not backe: he is or tane, or slaine.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Sit thee downe, Clitus: slaying is the word,
It is a deed in fashion. Hearke thee, Clitus.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: What I, my Lord? No, not for all the World.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Peace then, no words.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: Ile rather kill my selfe.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Hearke thee, Dardanius.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.l: Shall I doe such a deed?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: O Dardanius.

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.l: O Clitus

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: What ill request did Brutus make to thee?

sp.speaker: Dard.
sp.l: To kill him, Clitus: looke he meditates.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: Now is that Noble Vessell full of griefe, That it runnes ouer euen at his eyes

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Come hither, good Volumnius, list a word.

sp.speaker: Volum.
sp.l: What sayes my Lord?

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Why this, Volumnius
The Ghost of CÆsar hath appear'd to me
Two seuerall times by Night: at Sardis, once;
And this last Night, here in Philippi fields:
I know my houre is come.

sp.speaker: Volum.
sp.l: Not so, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Brut.
sp.l: Nay, I am sure it is, Volumnius.
Thou seest the World, Volumnius, how it goes,
Our Enemies haue beat vs to the Pit:
It is more worthy, to leape in our selues,
Then tarry till they push vs. Good Volumnius,
Thou know'st, that we two went to Schoole together:
Euen for that our loue of old, I prethee
Hold thou my Sword Hilts, whilest I runne on it.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: That's not an Office for a friend, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: Fly, flye my Lord, there is no tarrying heere.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Farewell to you, and you, and Volumnius.
Strato, thou hast bin all this while asleepe:
Farewell to thee, to Strato, Countrymen:
My heart doth ioy, that yet in all my life,
I found no man, but he was true to me.
I shall haue glory by this loosing day
More then Octauius, and Marke Antony,
By this vile Conquest shall attaine vnto.
So fare you well at once, for Brutus tongue
Hath almost ended his liues History:
Night hangs vpon mine eyes, my Bones would rest,
That haue but labour'd, to attaine this houre.

div.stage: Alarum. Cry within, Flye, flye, flye.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: Fly my Lord, flye.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Hence: I will follow:
I prythee Strato, stay thou by thy Lord,
Thou art a Fellow of a good respect:
Thy life hath had some smatch of Honor in it,
Hold then my Sword, and turne away thy face,
While I do run vpon it. Wilt thou Strato?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Giue me your hand first. Fare you wel my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Farewell good Strato. ⸺CÆsar, now be still,
I kill'd not thee with halfe so good a will.

div.stage:
Alarum. Retreat. Enter Antony, Octauius, Messala,
Lucillius, and the Army.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: What man is that?

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: My Masters man. Strato, where is thy Master?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Free from the Bondage you are in Messala,
The Conquerors can but make a fire of him:
For Brutus onely ouercame himselfe,
And no man else hath Honor by his death.

sp.speaker: Lucil.
sp.l: So Brutus should be found. I thank thee Brutus
That thou hast prou'd Lucillius saying true.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: All that seru'd Brutus, I will entertaine them.
Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: I, if Messala will preferre me to you.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Do so, good Messala.

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: How dyed my Master Strato?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: I held the Sword, and he did run on it.

sp.speaker: Messa.
sp.l: Octauius, then take him to follow thee,
That did the latest seruice to my Master.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This was the Noblest Roman of them all:
All the Conspirators saue onely hee,
Did that they did, in enuy of great Cæsar:
He, onely in a generall honest thought,
And common good to all, made one of them.
His life was gentle, and the Elements
So mixt in him, that Nature might stand vp,
And say to all the world; This was a man.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: According to his Vertue, let vs vse him
Withall Respect, and Rites of Buriall.
Within my Tent his bones to night shall ly,
Most like a Souldier ordered Honourably:
So call the Field to rest, and let's away,
To part the glories of this happy day.
